Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Extending current understanding of the complex role of institutions in both facilitating and hindering the effectiveness of social ventures, our research identifies conditions under which institutional infrastructures meant to coordinate action around a given social problem, unintendedly threaten the effectiveness of social ventures thriving to contribute to solving the problem. Our proposed theoretical framework suggests that, depending on the level of centralization and multiplicity of actors in the institutional infrastructure, social ventures face legitimating and organizing tensions that are likely to threaten their ability to address and manage social-business tensions and, thus, their ability to produce intended results. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Title: THE GEOGRAPHY OF GRANTMAKING-DOES LOCATION MATTER? NEIGHBORHOOD EFFECTS AND FOUNDATION PHILANTHROPY
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: The neighborhood effects scholarship in urban sociology demonstrates the importance of geographic location to social outcomes previously thought to be solely determined by individual characteristics (e.g. educational attainment). This article applies the neighborhood effects framework to the study of community-based nonprofits. If neighborhood composition and processes matter for individuals, do they also influence organizational outcomes such as resource procurement? An analysis of foundation grantmaking in the city of Chicago reveals that nonprofits' ability to secure grants is influenced by both organizational and neighborhood characteristics. While organizational factors matter, securing grants is also independently influenced by a nonprofit's neighborhood location. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Title: SOCIO-HISTORICAL SHIFTS IN LIFE STAGE AT ENTREPRENEURIAL ENTRY AND THEIR PERFORMANCE IMPLICATIONS
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Drawing on life course theory, we propose that shifting age norms have resulted in individuals today being younger, less experienced, and more frequently unmarried and childless at the time of entering entrepreneurship than in the past. We conjecture that these socio-historical shifts in life stage at entrepreneurial entry bear largely negative implications for entrepreneurial performance. Moreover, we argue for gender differences in the effect of parenthood on entrepreneurial performance, which we suggest have decreased over time due to the decline of traditional gender roles. Cohort analyses of data from the U.S. National Longitudinal Surveys of Youth support our conjectures. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Title: WELL-BEING, WORKPLACE AND RELIGION: INSIGHTS FROM THE MIDDLE EAST
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: This paper examines how religious practices and spiritual facilities may affect employees' well-being in workplaces. Based on Ryff's (1989) well-being framework, a related aim is to study the implications of spirituality for Ryff's (1989) model. Using a qualitative data from 22 employees, findings show that worshipping Allah, contemplative practices, and patience are key factors of one's psychological well-being. The study also highlights specific spiritual provisions and contemplative practices as key factors for enhancing Ryff's six dimensions of employees' psychological well-being. The paper offers a novel and contextual extension of Ryff's framework by theorizing the notion of well-being in Islam. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Abstract: Using a randomized control trial at the United States Patent and Trademark Office, we identify the heterogeneous causal impacts across gender and technologies of increased patent examination assistance on the probability of obtaining patent rights. Women applicants were 11 percentage points more likely than men to benefit from this assistance, and the benefits were largest for new inventors and in areas of technology where women had the worst relative outcomes. Our results suggest that a portion of the gender patenting gap could be eliminated through the provision of additional resources and assistance during patent prosecution. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Abstract: Corporate activism is when a firm takes a public stance on a social or political issue. Using semi-structured interviews with diverse stakeholders, a national survey on 525 corporate activist statements, and two pre-registered experiments, we find that the public generally supports corporate activism, but that a firm's type and moral authenticity substitute each other in shaping both attitudes and behaviors. Abstract: Who decides who is a bona fide member of the group? Abstract: Drawing on case study evidence, this study unpacks sustainability reporting's evolution from a moral values-based practice towards a financialized value-based one. Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: CEO succession may be a disruptive event and thus an opportune time for rivals to engage in competitive attacks against the focal firm, particularly when the successor is very different from the predecessor in terms of professional experience. Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Entrepreneurs often rely on experimentation to navigate the uncertainty of starting a new enterprise. While the benefits of experimental learning are mostly undisputed, we know little about its costs. I develop a stylized formal model to illustrate the key channels through which experimentation drives performance: information, adaptation, and appropriability. The model describes a nascent venture seeking to develop and commercialize a product based on an initial idea. The analysis suggests that experimentation is optimal only under certain organizational and environmental conditions. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Title: INSTITUTIONAL REFORMS AND ENTREPRENEURIAL GROWTH AMBITIONS
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: While institutional reforms have resulted in deep transformations of economies, accumulating insights about their effects have been inconclusive. Our study applies categorization theory to argue that flexibility- and stability-enhancing reforms may affect entrepreneurial growth ambitions in distinct ways, particularly depending on whether new versus established or innovative versus imitative entrepreneurs perceive specific reforms as an opportunity or a threat. Our findings, drawn from a multisource and multilevel dataset, indicate that flexibility-enhancing reforms lead to higher growth ambitions particularly for established and for imitative entrepreneurs. On the contrary, stability-enhancing reforms lead to higher growth ambitions of new and innovative entrepreneurs. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Abstract: We examine changes in newcomers' emotional labor process during their first year to answer the research question of how and why newcomers experience changes in emotional labor. Title: INSTITUTIONAL HARMONIZATION AND INTERNATIONAL CONNECTIVITY IN INNOVATION
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: In this paper, we study the relationship between harmonization in formal institutions and international connectivity in innovation. We investigate the role of MNEs as pipelines for knowledge connectivity. Utilizing Turkey's candidacy for the EU, we apply principal component analysis and linear aggregation methods, and use textual analysis to track Turkey's history of institutional upgrade. We also utilize USPTO patent data and geographical information to analyze the international connectivity of co-inventor teams. We find preliminary support for the relationship between formal institutional harmonization and international connectivity in innovation. Our initial findings also indicate MNEs' asymmetrical mediative role contingent on both their origins and type of formal institution. Our study aims to contribute to the literature by opening the black box of connectivity and presenting institutional fundamentals as antecedents of international connectedness and empirically showing the role of MNEs as pipelines in knowledge linkages that is conditional on both the origin of the MNE and the type of regulations. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Abstract: This study aims to investigate when, how and why fathers' work-family conflicts influence their adult offspring's earnings. Building on conservation of resource (COR) theory and social information processing (SIP) theory, we propose a moderated mediation model that suggests that for fathers experiencing greater (as opposed to lower) social isolation, fathers' work-family conflicts will have a stronger indirect effect on children's earnings 17 years later via the sequential mechanisms of vitality and children's hope of success. Our full model is supported by 17 years of dyadic father-child data (N = 592) from the Household, Income and Labor Dynamics in Australia (HILDA) Survey. Abstract: We offer a different and novel perspective on the 'business case' for female representation in the upper echelons. Abstract: We study if men and women with similar job-relevant characteristics write their resumes differently, and how this difference affects hiring outcomes. Using a matched sample set of resumes (348k resumes), we train a deep learning model to inductively learn differences between male and female resumes with similar job-relevant characteristics. We use this model to develop a measure of gender-incongruence - i.e., measure of how much the self-presented gender characteristics in the resume deviate from the self-reported gender of the candidate. Title: AN ETHICS OF EMBODIMENT ACCOUNT OF DISABILITY AT WORK DURING THE GLOBAL PANDEMIC
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: An 15-month longitudinal study of 22 disabled workers navigating paid (self)employment in UK-based organizations foregrounded two distinct ways in which bodies mediated the meaningfulness of everyday work in times of crises. When disabled workers enrolled their bodies as sites of resistance to daily violations of their rights, needs, and expectations, embodied performances deflated the meaningfulness of work. When disabled workers leveraged their bodies as sites of representation for their rights, needs, and expectations, embodied performances inflated work meaningfulness. This dual ethics of embodiment account explains the centrality of bodies in securing the meaningfulness of everyday work during the global pandemic. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Abstract: Using a mixed-methods approach, we explore the effects of crises on the way a narcissistic leader employs charismatic rhetoric and subsequently the way his charismatic leadership is viewed by followers as they make leader selection decisions during a national crisis. Study 1 suggests that during times of crisis, charismatic rhetoric became more self-focused than group-focused. Our findings from Study 2 suggest that crisis influenced perceptions of charisma and leader selection, with leader narcissism playing a moderating role. Abstract: Given that considering general mental ability (GMA) improves the quality of selection decisions, the present studies examined whether mindsets influence willingness to incorporate such data when predicting job candidates' future job performance. Against the backdrop of hundreds of studies lauding the merits of growth mindsets, the present results suggest the imperative for the mindsets literature to adopt a more contingent conception of when holding a growth mindset may be (dys)functional. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Abstract: The subscription-based business model is disruptive in the copy-right industries. However, it remains unknown about how and why it affects the local traditional industry. This study investigates its impact on offline activity consumption in the motion picture industry. Leveraging individuals' every transaction record and a difference-in-differences approach, we conclude that Netflix subscription increases offline movie consumption. We support that individuals have unmet hedonic and social demands with the imperfect disruptive technology. They, therefore, attend more hedonic and social activities (movies, dining, entertainment), which is more pronounced for individuals with such needs. Title: EFFICIENT INDUSTRIAL POLICY FOR INNOVATION: STANDING ON THE SHOULDERS OF HIDDEN GIANTS?
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Knowledge spillovers drive a wedge between private and social returns to R&D. Efficient innovation policy assigns subsidies to fields where spillovers are relatively important. We develop new measures for the private and spillover value of patented innovations and embed these in a structural microeconomic model to estimate field-specific marginal returns to R&D support. We find that expected returns to subsidy vary strongly by field and country, suggesting that targeted innovation policy has large potential to increase welfare. Because spillovers cross country borders, we find that supranational coordination of innovation policy offers large potential efficiency gains, especially for smaller countries. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Title: R&D COLLABORATION WITH COMMON PARTNERS AND KNOWLEDGE LEAKAGE TO RIVALS: THE ROLE OF IP LITIGATION
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: We argue that knowledge leakage may occur to rival firms through indirect ties, i.e., if rivals collaborate on R&D with a common partner, but that firms with an aggressive patent litigation strategy may be able to restrict such knowledge spillovers. We expect knowledge leakage to be more prominent, and litigation strategy to be less powerful, when the common partner is a university or public research institution adhering to the open science paradigm, compared with when the common partner is another (non-rival) firm. Patent citation analysis among dyads of leading pharmaceutical firms provides qualified support for these hypotheses. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Title: ENTREPRENEURS' EUDAIMONIC WELL-BEING: MULTIPLE ROADS LEAD TO ROME

Abstract: We contribute to entrepreneurship and well-being research by shedding light on the role of individuals' value priorities in explaining their occupational choices and, ultimately, their well-being. Through analyzing European Social Survey (ESS) data, we empirically demonstrate that individual value priorities for benevolence and self-direction distinctively affect individuals' choices for entrepreneurship in 'socially-oriented' sectors and in 'commercially-oriented' sectors, which in turn differentially affect their perceived autonomy and meaningfulness in life. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Title: HOW RELEVANT IS IRRELEVANT INFORMATION? THE EFFECT OF NON-DIAGNOSTIC INFORMATION ON LEADERSHIP PERCEPTIONS
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Previous studies have provided conflicting evidence of whether irrelevant information can influence the processing of relevant information in behavioral judgments. Under the term dilution effect, Nisbett, Zukier and Lemley (1981) suggest that irrelevant information bring individuals' judgements to the mid-point of a scale. By using dilution effect explanations, we examine whether irrelevant information makes leadership ratings less extreme or not. Results of the present study demonstrate that the effect of irrelevant information was dependent on the context i.e., leadership ratings of targets with positive behaviors information were reduced whereas leadership ratings of targets with negative behavior information were increased. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Title: DOES IT PAY TO STAND OUT? EXAMINING THE EFFECT OF GENDER DISSIMILARITY ON WOMEN'S PAY IN TECH
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: We examine how managers within firms respond to external pressures for gender equity, with a focus on women's pay in technology firms. We argue that the extent to which managers respond to gender equity pressures will depend on their subordinates' gender dissimilarity from the workgroup. Specifically, we theorize that women who are more dissimilar from their workgroups will receive higher pay. We further theorize that this positive effect will be stronger for women in technical roles and is driven by managers' impression management concerns and perceptions of women's work-related capabilities. Abstract: Many entrepreneurial development programs like accelerators use mentors to help entrepreneurs understand when to pivot. Abstract: Research on data production often aims to unpack the nature and work practices related to data. Abstract: Research on award-winning CEOs have led to two contradictory assertions: some scholars argue that CEOs who win awards may engage in strategic change and risk-taking behavior, while others argue that such CEOs become risk-averse and are less likely to engage in strategic change. Abstract: Cross-sector partnerships (CSPs) are typically organized around a specific social goal which implies that, once achieved, the partnership can wind down or repurpose. Abstract: While there is evidence that organizations are not permanent, scholars and practitioners often treat them as active or completely defunct. Abstract: This study aims to push Effectuation forward as an advanced entrepreneurship theory through a qualitative study of the alliance between technology-based academic entrepreneurs and large firms. The research findings reveal how academic entrepreneurs' tendency to allocate their own resources contributes to trust-building; and how large firms apply affordable loss in order to protect their strategic resources against uncertain partnerships. These findings enhance the validity and scope of the means-based principle and affordable loss by splitting them into dimensions. Title: MEANS VERSUS ENDS IN BUSINESS ETHICS: A BEHAVIOURAL TRADE-OFF BETWEEN COMPLIANCE AND ACHIEVEMENT OF CORPORATE ETHICS PROGRAMMES
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: This paper discusses the compliance-achievement trade-off of corporate ethics programmes. To bridge gaps between moral intentions and actual choices of employees, ethics officers commonly emphasise compliance with a narrow subset of enforceable rules. However, compliance inducement might hinder an organisation's broader value-oriented ethics goals. This trade-off prevails especially in complex organisational settings that are prone to trigger ethical fading, whereby the moral intentions of ethically-bounded humans become opaque. I define conditions for a corporate ethics approach under which the trade-off can be reduced and explore the behavioural concept of nudging as one possible approach that could fulfil the defined conditions. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Title: WHAT ALLOWS A STAR TO SHINE? EVIDENCE FROM THE MANHATTAN PROJECT
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Inspired by recent work that connects stars' work environment to their productivity, this manuscript employs an aspirational and information-processing capability lens to uncover variance in star scientists' novel knowledge output. For the aspirational lens, we distinguish between rising and established stars. For the information-processing capability lens, we differentiate between specialist and generalist star scientists. We use participation in the Manhattan Project, a large-scale research project that created the atomic bomb, as a quasi-natural experiment and find that stars' environment impacts novelty and that rising stars and generalists are more influenced by this effect than established stars and specialists. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Title: KNOWLEDGE PROBLEMS: FAULT LINES IN THE EXTERNAL ENABLEMENT OF ENTREPRENEURIAL ACTION?
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Entrepreneurial action takes place under conditions of unknowingness. These conditions represent a set of knowledge problems that an entrepreneur faces. Yet, research on the accurate diagnosis and sources of knowledge problems leading to entrepreneurial action remains underdeveloped. Identification of the sources of knowledge problems and incorporation of the mechanisms through which knowledge problems impact entrepreneurial action are needed to advance entrepreneurial action theory. We derive propositions that explain the sources and effects of knowledge problems, resulting in a middle-range theory of entrepreneurial action. By identifying the role of the external environment and associated changes as sources of knowledge problems, we bridge the gap between macro-level environmental changes and micro-level entrepreneurial action. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Abstract: In this paper, we develop theory by focusing on the resource-dependance, social judgments and institutional determinants of an organization's decision to join an association. Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Non-practicing entities (NPEs) are firms that build patent portfolios but do not implement the patented technologies in any products, processes, or services (known as patent trolls). NPEs initiate lawsuits primarily not to stop patent infringement, but for the potential monetary profits. We examine how firms shift their innovation strategies in response to heightened NPE litigation risks. Abstract: We discuss how Multinationals' R&D evolves in its subsidiaries in emerging markets and if they can affect the MNE's global R&D strategy. Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: In this study, we examine the comparative advantage of different types of new market entrants. We distinguish between three types of entrants-diversifying entrants, entrepreneurial spinouts, and de novo startups-and use a simulation model to study their relative performance as a function of market relatedness and complexity. We find that diversifying entrants have superior initial performance, but are eventually dominated by entrepreneurial spinouts, especially if relatedness is moderate and complexity is moderate to high. Abstract: We examine the antecedents of successful collective action among heterogeneous actors. Using a simulation-based approach, we explore the effect of three parameters-cooperativeness, heterogeneity of claims, and heterogeneity of capabilities-on the extent to which actors in a population contribute towards their collective good. Our results show that cooperativeness is neither necessary nor sufficient for collective action; where actors are heterogeneous, collective action fails even with full cooperativeness. Title: BRINGING IN A NEUTRAL PARTY: DEMOGRAPHIC FAULTLINES AND THE APPOINTMENT OF AN OUTSIDER BOARD CHAIR
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Sociopolitical models of board governance posit that directors split into factions, often along demographic lines, potentially increasing conflict that hurts the board's functioning. Yet little knowledge exists about how boards adapt their composition or leadership to reduce conflict. In this study, we develop theory to propose that boards with strong demographic faultlines between factions will seek a compromise by appointing an outsider board chair. We further argue that the strength of this relationship depends on the likelihood of conflict across faultlines, the availability of an alternative impartial leader on the board, and the salience of pressures from outside the board. Analyses on a sample of 1,345 non-CEO board chair appointments at S&P 1500 firms between the years 2003 and 2017 support our hypotheses. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Abstract: Unique strategies are critical for creating competitive advantage but impose a greater information burden on investors to appraise and can be discounted on the market, leading firms to compromise on uniqueness. Abstract: Even a decade after its initial introduction, the interest in evolving the Industry 4.0 concept remains high in academia and industrial practice. Title: WHY FIRMS HIDE THEIR LIGHT: BROWNWASH, SILENCE, AND BIFURCATED STAKEHOLDER COMMUNICATION
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: In the face of rapidly increasing public pressure, numerous firms are rushing to trumpet their environmental and social achievements on net-zero, ESG metrics, and justice and inequality commitments to anyone who will listen. While claims of greenwashing abound and are the subject of increasing scrutiny, many firms making real changes have, paradoxically, chosen to downplay and understate their accomplishments. In this paper we draw on emerging literature on brownwashing and silence to offer a comprehensive study of why and how firms undertake such activities, linking extant insights as well as offering a novel model and reconceptualization. Our rich qualitative study with leaders at over 50 North American wineries allows us to offer in depth and in situ insights. Our findings, first, highlight new mechanisms of non-communication not yet identified in this emerging literature. Second, our analysis offers the important insight that firms don't simply hide their achievements in a reactive manner to avoid negative stakeholder pressures, as in current theory, but also do so when their practices are leading or more proactive than those of stakeholders. Finally, we examine three strategies by which firms divide and conquer through what we term bifurcated stakeholder communications: locational, channel, and temporal. This study also has important practical implications as society, policymakers, and NGOs seek to drive industry change on social and environmental grand challenges, and strive to engage firms publicly in leading change and addressing these challenges. © 2022 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022.All rights reserved.

Abstract: Metric conjoint studies are a popular research design in the entrepreneurship domain to model a respondent's decision-making processes. Informed by a comprehensive literature review, we conducted a Monte Carlo simulation to evaluate the effect of various test-retest reliabilities in conjoint experiments. Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Corporate venturing (CV) plays a fundamental role in the strategic renewal of established companies. In the past decade, Corporate Accelerator (CA) programs have increasingly been adopted across industries as a more radical CV form of corporate experimentation. Yet, academic research on CAs is in its infancy, with a nascent but growing body of work only emerging over the past 5-6 years. This aims to accelerate CA research in academia by understanding the roots, and evolution of extant literature, and drawing a path for the future. We examine the scholar origins of CV research tracing the way from its roots to the nascence of CAs in 2016 and beyond. Along this track, we map the core literature, identifying main academic contexts, mechanisms, and outcomes across CV intermediaries so as to provide an organizing framework for the emerging field of CA. We do this by applying a structured mixed method literature review from 1981-2021, combining bibliometric analyses (co-citation and citation analysis) with a subsequent detailed qualitative analysis, following a CIMO (context, intermediary, mechanism, outcome) inductive framework. Abstract: With increasing conflicts and discrimination in organizations, scholars have become increasingly interested in the role of inclusive leadership in the workplace. Title: INTRAORGANIZATIONAL DYNAMICS IN ORGANIZATIONAL STIGMATIZATION
Source title: 82nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2022: A Hybrid Experience, AOM 2022
Abstract: Why do some organizations choose to fight stigma while others accept their stigmatized status and seek to reform themselves in an effort to overcome it? Research on organizational stigma has made large strides in the past two decades, yet intra-organizational processes that condition the lived experience of those who are stigmatized have remained black-boxed. We examine how intra-organizational dynamics affect the process of organizational stigmatization through an empirical case of a public broadcaster that initially experienced episodic stigmatization. We demonstrate how internal contention in the organization favored those who opposed the stigma, leading to an organizational response characterized by defiance and denial. This reinforced audience disapproval of the broadcaster, leading to core stigmatization-the discounting of the organization as a whole based on a core identity. Our study contributes to understanding stigma not as an attribute but as a process, where the nature of stigma is susceptible to change not only due to environmental factors but also as a result of the actions (and inactions) of the stigmatized organization. Abstract: Copreneurs, entrepreneurial couples who jointly own and operate their business, are considered the smallest yet important unit of a family business.
